text:
I was born into a family of four: my parents, my older brother, and me. We lived in a small town, and although it was safe and comfortable, I often felt the urge to explore and experience the world beyond the boundaries of our sleepy village.

Growing up, I was an introverted child who kept to myself. I was never one to start conversations, but I enjoyed listening to others. I was content to simply observe the goings-on around me and take it all in. I spent my childhood days quietly, often daydreaming in my own little world. 

My parents were supportive and encouraging, but I never felt like I could truly share my thoughts and feelings with them. I was an emotional person, but I kept my emotions bottled up inside and rarely expressed them. I was often too afraid to ask for help or advice, and I was reluctant to take any risks.

I tried to make friends, but I was always too shy and awkward. I was the type of person who preferred to stay in the background and watch others interact. I was never comfortable in large groups and kept to myself in most social settings. I was often the last one picked for sports teams, and I was usually the last one to speak up in class. 

I was also a bit of an outsider when it came to my peers. I was never one to follow trends or fit into the popular crowd, but I didn't feel like I was a complete misfit either. I was content to quietly observe others from the sidelines.

My brother was my opposite in many ways. He was outgoing, confident, and more sociable than me. He often tried to draw me out of my shell, but I usually shut down and retreated back into my comfort zone. I never felt like I could be myself around him, and I was often too intimidated to speak up.

I kept to myself for most of my childhood, but I eventually found my place in the world. I discovered my passion for art and writing, and I began to express myself through my creative work. I also found solace in books and movies, which allowed me to escape into my own little world and explore different perspectives. 

As I grew older, I became more confident in myself and my abilities. I started to take risks and embrace new opportunities. I was still an introvert, but I was open to new experiences and more willing to push myself out of my comfort zone. 

My childhood may have been quiet and uneventful, but it also shaped me into the person I am today. I'm still introverted, but I'm also open to new experiences and willing to take risks. I'm still cautious and guarded, but I'm also more confident and independent than I used to be. I may not be the most outgoing person, but I'm comfortable in my own skin and I'm content with who I am.
prompt:

Here are a number of characteristics that may or may not apply to you. For example, do you agree that you are someone who likes to spend time with others? Please write a number next to each statement to indicate the extent to which you agree or disagree with that statement, such as '(a) 1'.

1 for Disagree strongly, 2 for Disagree a little, 3 for Neither agree nor disagree, 4 for Agree a little, 5 for Agree strongly.
